sentence.text: Samsung's Flagship-model,GALAXY S5, having Snapdragon 801 and RAM = 2GB on.
The characteristic is a embossment in a dot shape.
Although people either like this unique dry texture or don't like it, personally i like it.
Corresponding waterproofing of IP67, so: into the water, no problem.
The Packing on the Back Panel prevent from the water.
Though this is the well-known waterproofing terminal in Japan, but I'm glad the popular brand Samsung correspond it.
To put on and take off the battery pack, need to remove the back panel.
If you have charged the spare battery pack, and carry it, you could cope with the batteries going flat.
The earphone jack is capless waterproofing, microUSB terminal with the cap.
When the Charging on the desktop holder, it's needless about opening and shutting the cap, so, this enable the waterproofing performance to maintain long time.
When the equipping on the desktop holder, starting the original launcher.
In the horizontal screen mode, you can access the watch, TV, Schedule, Gallery, etc.
Although GALAXY S5 is the bigger size 5.1" than iPhone 5s(4"), it is the mainstream size of Android smartphone, for example, Xperia Z2.
A little lighter than Xperia Z2, So-so Carrying easiness.
About the Display, they adopted OLED, with the very nice viewing angle and color development, can be asserted against iPhone 5s or Xperia Z2.
Though this may be a little loud color development, you can change on the settings screen.
About the fingerprint authentication sensor with a built in the home button, by sliding the finger vertically, fingerprint recognition.
This sensor can unlocking the screen lock as well as specifying the images or movies don't want to show, to protect your privacy.
About The lower part of camera, with a built in the heart rate monitor, and you can measure your heart rate.
You can start the camera from the lock screen.
The speed of focus and the image stabilization improved.
For example the screenshot photography by sliding the palm of the hand, or hover function, and so on.
This smartphone follows a long-familiar function, especially since the multi-window display the various App in a simultaneous process, so very useful.
With watching Youtube or Map,You can work.
As well as, You can simultaneously launch the Browser and Google Chrome.
You can do any works, with displaying TV broadcasting or the movies in the small window.
In the Home screen, ss compared before Galaxy S4, the animation is different.
And, by the right flick, App 'magazine' appeared, I thought it is an obstacle.
To return the previous status before Galaxy S4, by long pressing the blank space of Home screen, and change the Settings of Home screen.
Then, 'magazine' is doesn't start.
To rearrange the App drawer, press the menu button on the top right corner, and tap the Notification panel.long press the Icon, and drag it 'create folder'.
Input the Folder Name, and Designate Icon want to add a folder altogether, then you can rearrange easily.
It have an effect to hide the useless App, for example Mobile operator's App, Google's App, Samsung's App.
You can also customize the toggle switch on the Notification Bar.

aspectTerm.term: toggle switch on the Notification Bar

sentence.text: Long tap, and rearrange the Icons.
The New function from Galaxy S5.
The Toolbox can display shortcut of App, at all times.
With One Hand Mode, and so on.
Since the screen can be reduced,It's useful For the Women and the Children with the small hand, as well as,For the Japanese Train Commuting one hand is full for holding a strap.
This is the Samsung CM, "Wall Huggers" advertise the superiority to Galaxy S5's battery duration time.
As the reason why this Galaxy S5's battery longer than iPhone 5s, because of the exchangeable battery pack, and Ultra Saving Mode.
By being a monochrome screen, reducing the battery power consumption overwhelmingly, special to OLED.
Under the Ultra Saving Mode, regardless of remaining battery 10%, possible to 24 hour phone waiting, it's useful when the disaster come, for example earthquake.
There are many glad points for Japanese, for example waterproofing or One Hand Mode.
So, this is a very nice smartphone in this term.
Samsung has enjoyed a bumper year since the release of the Samsung Galaxy S4, and it's now trying to keep the good times rolling with the Samsung Galaxy S5.
It looks to be a worthy flagship, but does it have what it takes to fend off the chasing pack?
If you want to know more at any point during the review, just click the Phones 4u logo to be taken to our website.
Fingerprint scanners are all the rage at the moment, and the S5 is the latest to join the party.
It's situated over the home button and can store multiple fingers depending on how you hold your handset.
Set up is straightforward and use is pretty easy, although it can be a bit awkward to adjust to unlocking your device with it.

Your prints can also be used to verify your Samsung account and make PayPal payments, so there's an extra element of security to the things that matter, something we're hoping will extend to more apps in the future.
Sticking with finger reading, Samsung has also dialled up the handset's S Health integration with a heart rate monitor.
Situated under the camera lens it can track your pulse in a few short seconds, a good indicator for seeing how hard you're working out.

And when you combine it with existing features like the pedometer, which can show whether you're walking or running, and the in depth graphs and trackers, it's easy to see the effort you're putting in at a glance.
The S5 is water and dust resistant to IP67 rating, so you don't have to worry about a few splashes on the 5.1-inch full HD display when you're out exercising.

aspectTerm.term: water and dust resistant to IP67 rating

sentence.text: As you would expect the handset's design reflects this, with a covered USB port and a sliver plastic bezel forming a tight seal around the edges.
There's little to change to the general handset shape but there has been a growth in dimensions and theres no escaping it's a big handset.
The rear cover now features a smart dimple motif.
The new design looks and feels nice and we're pleased to see some changes, although the plastic material may not be to everyone's taste.
There's also been a few changes inside thanks to Android KitKat and Samsung.
The OS offers excellent organisation, such as space for your favourite text message recipients, while the firm's UI is bright, clear and responsive.
My Magazine now has a dedicated swipe to the left, and the Settings menu has be excellently resigned to be more organised and intuitive.
The menu is broken down into specific areas, so there's no more swiping about searching for a feature.
One feature that Samsung is particularly proud of is Download Booster.
This combines Wi-Fiand 4G when downloading an item over 30MB, so you can get things done a lot faster.
There's even an option to see just how rapidly you're doing it.
Going fast is something you'll experience all over the S5, especially with the 2.5 GHz quad-core processor.
It's currently one of the biggest on the market and it shows.
Multitasking is seamless and it offers near flawless performance, even when you're running demanding content.
A 2800mAh battery means the S5's stamina will also impress.
We managed to get a day and a bit's use out of a full charge, although you can expect this to decrease with heavy gaming or streaming.
But even then your charge can be elongated with Power saving mode, an invaluable feature that can keep you going for 24 hours on 10% by limiting app access and using grey scale.
Speed and performance also extends to the camera, and the S5's 16 megapixel sensor can autofocus and capture in 0.3 seconds.
This really is fast, and we're impressed at how soon you can have the camera on and snap an image.
There are plenty of features on offer, such as Selective Focus which lets you blur the foreground or background after capture.
Modes like Action Shot return from the S4, which has had a makeover to encompass things like Eraser in one handy package.
You can even take your own 3D image to explore with Virtual tour shot.
But the headline has to be 4k video capture, which lets you shoot in twice HD.
Although you can't enjoy the full benefit on the S5's 1080p screen it still looks stunning, as does everything else.
Connect it to a UHD TV and you will be suitably impressed.
If that's not enough you can also record video in 1080p at 60 fps.
The Samsung Galaxy S5 had a tough act to follow, but the firm has done a great job by improving on key aspects.
The handset is a solid step forward from its predecessors and, as a standalone handset, has an awful lot to offer.
Don't forget to hit that thumbs up button and subscribe to our YouTube channel to watch the full review as soon as it goes live.
You can also read our written review by clicking the link in the description below.
One of the biggest smartphone launches of 2014.
It's the brand new flagship from Samsung!
The Samsung S5!
This the variant from Sprint, the nation's third largest wireless provider, with the model number SM-G900P.
I'm Muwen360.
Let's get into the review.
The Samsung Galaxy S5 is the latest phone from Samsung.
It succeeds the S4 to become Samsung's new flagship device.
You can get this from Sprint for $199 with a 2 year contract or $649 unlocked.
The biggest shocker that a lot of people had with the S5 when it was first announced, was the material they chose for the back of the phone.
It's this soft-touch matte finish with many little dimples on the back.
And a lot of people thought it was ugly and unnecessary so on and so forth.
But in reality, at least from a person that played around with the phone, I can tell you that the material on the back is a real pleasure to hold.
Granted it might not be as pretty as the HTC One M8 or the iPhone 5S, but the back of the phone on the S5 serves a great purpose.
First of all, it rejects fingerprints extremely well when you compare it to previous phones from Samsung that had that glossy finish on the back.
My favorite part about the back is that it's very easy to grip and hold the phone with those little dimples because they really allow your fingers to have good traction to hold the phone.
Plus, just the nature of that soft-touch matte finish on the back makes it really comfortable to hold it the hand which is another thing that I like.

aspectTerm.term: soft-touch matte finish on the back

sentence.text: Overall the design of the back really isn't as bad as some people say.
It might not the prettiest thing in the world but it works really well.
The design for the rest phone is very similar to the S4.
We've still got the fake metal ring around the phone and the tapered edges.
So very similar in terms of design between the S4 and the S5.
The GS5 is slightly bigger that the S4.
It measures to 5.59 inches tall by 2.85 inches wide by 0.32-inch thick.
So slightly heavier than the S4 due to the extra hardware but still very light to carry around.
The home button just ever-so-slightly more capsule-shaped.
Also less clicky too in my opinion due to that fingerprint scanner which I'll explain later.
And of course we still have the capacitive multi tasking and back keys.
The display of the S5 is an improvement over the S4.
It's got that full 1080p Super AMOLED HD display.
1920x1080 resolution screen with a pixel density of 432 pixels per inch.

aspectTerm.term: pixel density of 432 pixels per inch

sentence.text: The screen is absolutely gorgeous.
One of the best phone displays on the market right now.
Images are extremely crisp and colorful, with good contrast.
Photos and videos look really great.
The display can get pretty bright and you also get a wide viewing angle which is really nice.
I've also noticed that it's better at reducing glare as well.
External controls are where you expect them on a Samsung phone: power is on the right, volume buttons on the left.
3.5 millimeter headphone jack up top, next to the IR blaster.
On the back, we have the new heart rate monitor that is integrated with the camera's LED flash.
The USB 3.0 charging port is a little different.
It now has a little flap door which you now need to peel open whenever you want to access it.
It is a little annoying to do it every time you want to use it but it was necessary for that IP67 certification for water and dust resistance.

aspectTerm.term: IP67 certification for water and dust resistance

sentence.text: The 6 means the phone can be completely submerged by water 3 feet for about 30 minutes.
The 7 means that it's completely resistant to all dust.
And also the back of the phone is removable and you do have access through that to the lithium-ion battery.
For the user interface, the GS5 runs Android 4.4 KitKat with Samsung's own TouchWiz customizations.
In the GS5, you get a updated version of TouchWiz which is a huge improvement over previous versions.
Samsung kind of tweaked it to freshen up its look and feel.
The icons are more modern and flat.
It also has less pre-loaded Samsung apps which is nice but there is still Sprint pre-installed stuff though.
The interface does have the magazine screen carried over from the Galaxy Tab Pro line.
What it essentially does is give you a Flipboard style magazine which is fine for what it does.
But it might bother a lot of people like me that you can't get rid of the magazine screen because it does get in the way sometimes.
The settings menu is updated and you get more sorting options so you can get access to the setting you want faster.
So thumbs up to Samsung for doing that.
A pretty awesome feature they built into the S5 is the new multi-tasking capability.
It allows you to run two separate apps simultaneously to really boost your productivity.
Very cool and useful in a lot of situations and definitely worth checking out.
The Galaxy S5 is very fast and responsive thanks to its 2.5 GHz Qualcomm Snapdragon 801 Quad-core processor with that Adreno 330 graphics.
Everything loads up really fast and definitely a high-performing phone as you would expect it to be.
The camera on the Galaxy S5 is amazing.
I'd say it has one of the best cameras out there for a phone right now.
It has a 16 megapixel camera on the back that has auto focus with LED flash.
The front facing camera is a 2 megapixel camera.
Samsung has definitely improved in the camera department.
Photos that you take with the phone look really good.
Colors are rich and they really natural.
The camera does also have 4K ultra HD video recording capabilities.
You get a ton of settings and features in the camera app which is also improved.
You can make tons of edits and quick adjustments to your pictures right in the app which is very cool.

aspectTerm.term: edits and quick adjustments to your pictures

sentence.text: Overall, great camera for taking pictures and shooting pictures and if you're someone that take a lot pictures with your phone, you're really going to like the camera on the S5.
As for the battery life, it's got a decent sized 2,800 mill ampere battery.
The battery lasted around 10 hours for me with 4G, GPS on and some gaming and internet browsing so it should get you through the day without any problem.
Alright so now I want to get into the two most hyped features of the Galaxy S5 and that is number 1 the fingerprint scanner and number 2 the heart rate monitor.
So I'll first talk about the fingerprint scanner.
So the fingerprint scanner on the Galaxy S5 is probably inspired by the fingerprint print scanner on the iPhone 5S and it works okay on the S5.
I mean it works and if you do it correctly, it will unlock your phone.
But it's not always accurate.
Sometimes it works.
Sometimes it doesn't so the results you get will vary.
So the fingerprint scanner is cool and everything even though it doesn't work as well as the one on iPhone 5S.
It's still valid choice if you want to have another way to secure and unlock your phone.
Next, the heart rate monitor is a new thing.
The Galaxy S5 is the first to have this feature.
You can access it through the S Health app and to use just put your finger on the sensor located in the back of the phone and it measures heart rate.
It tells you your heart rate after 10, 15 seconds and that's basically what it does.
The heart rate monitor might be a great feature for people when their exercising to easily know how fast their heart is beating.
So the uses are different for different people.
It's cool to have it but it's really not a feature that I think everybody could take advantage of.

So overall the Samsung Galaxy S5 is basically with the exception of a few non essential hardware and software additions -- like the fingerprint scanner and the heart-rate monitor -- and a few design tweaks here and there, you're pretty much looking at the same phone Samsung released last year, the Galaxy S4.

So the Galaxy S5 is really an evolutionary upgrade over the S4 and that is why a lot people are calling it the Galaxy S4 Plus so I'd say if you have the S4 right now, I'd say this is an upgrade you could skip and perhaps wait until year when Samsung hopefully will release a more revolutionary Galaxy S6.
But you're someone that is in the market for a brand new phone to replace your old one, this could be a great option for you.
It's got everything you would ever want in a smartphone, good camera, fast processor and you really can't go wrong with the S5 in terms of performance.
So this will wrap up review of the Samsung Galaxy S5 and if you enjoyed this review, please hit the like button down below since it would help me a lot.
And don't forget to subscribe for more reviews like this in the future.
Stay tuned for more videos and I'll see you guys later.
Despite the complaints about its design and reviewers moaning, the Samsung Galaxy S5 has achieved a great commercial success with over 10 million global sales in 25 days.
How did a device disappoint reviewers and consumers but at the same time is selling like hot cakes?
There are two possible scenarios: 1.
The Galaxy S5 is pretty capable overall - 2.
The Galaxy S5 owners are a barking dog that never bites.
This is Sakis Karpas in another episode of Unboxholics and this is the Samsung Galaxy S5, the flagship of all flagship smartphones not in terms of tech specs but in everything else.
Samsung sent us the review unit of the smartphone, so there's no unboxing.
Let's start with the design.

The Galaxy S5's design follows an identical design path like the previous entries in the Galaxy Series and that is plastic materials of good quality accompanied by nickel details on the outline of the smartphone's body and a back side texture that has a velvet and leather feeling at the same time.

Although there are smartphones currently available in the market with better overall build quality, the back side texture of the Samsung Galaxy S5 makes us feel that the smartphone is safe in our hands and its delicate design is enough to satisfy us.
Let's take a look at the smartphone's dimensions.

Height: 142 mm x Width: 72.5 mm x Thickness: 8.1 mm Weight: 145 g (quite normal proportionally to its size) Front side: 1x calls speaker, Screen sensors and 1x 2MP camera that is capable of 1080p 30FPS video recording.
The home button has fingerprint scanning capabilities which we'll analyse in a bit and next to it we found the usual function buttons.

Bottom side: Micro-USB port and 1x microphone, the volume button of the device can be found on the left side along with the power button on the right side while its headphones port, its noise cancellation microphone and its IR Blaster are situated on the top side.
The back side features a 16MP camera, a LED flash and the device's main speaker which although it does not sound as clear as we would have liked, its bass and volume levels are satisfying.
The back flexible cover of the Galaxy S5 can be removed to give access to the phone's battery, the SIM card slot and the MicroSD slot.
Samsung Galaxy S5's IP67 certification means that it can stand with a lot of water and dust.
Despite our mini-heart attacks while doing the tests, it made us proud.
And we guess the Samsung engineers will be too.
Keep in mind that you need to make sure that the back cover of your Galaxy S5 has been secured tightly in its place and that the Micro USB port is closed with its cap.
If you do these two things, you don't have to worry about your Galaxy S5 being near water.
Most complaints about the Galaxy S5 rise from its technical specifications.
A lot of people awaited the next big step from Samsung but the South Korean based company decided to stick with the present.
The Galaxy S5 is powered by the Snapdragon 801 chipset with a Krait 400 Quad-Core CPU clocked at 2.5GHz and an Adreno 330 GPU.
RAM: 2 GB Storage: 16/32 GB expandable up to 128 GB via microSD, Display: Gorilla Glass 3, Super AMOLED 1080p, 432 ppi.
In our opinion, Samsung Galaxy S5's battery is one of its greatest selling points.
With a 2800 mAh Li-Po battery, the device lasted up to two days at full brightness levels, GPS, cellular data and Wi-Fi on, it lasted up to two days before we had to recharge it.
This is more than satisfying.
Samsung Galaxy S5 supports all 3G/4G LTE networks.
One of the most disappointing things about the Galaxy S5 is its fingerprint sensor.
It may have been approved by Paypal for quick transactions, it may be able to recognize different fingers and comes with several functions but it is still a useless feature, at least in our opinion.
The Galaxy S5 ships with Android 4.4.2 but it has been customized to a big extent by Samsung.
The Magazine UI, as Samsung calls it, is muffled with a lot of features and apps like the S Health, S Voice, Gestures, Emergency mode and Baby Cry recognition.
All these are welcome but they fill up the device and the user, draining power from the phone for no reason.
Another disappointing feature of the smartphone is the "My Magazine" app which shows media from your favorite websites and social media, not only fails to load sometimes but it is slow overall.

One of the most useful features of the device though is the Ultra Saving Mode which changes your screen to black and white and shuts down all unnecessary features to dramatically minimize battery consumption.

What we love about the Samsung Galaxy S5 more than anything else is its display which is probably one of the best smartphone displays we've ever seen with incredible brightness, realistic and vivid colors and excellent viewing angles.
If you were waiting for a 2K display, Samsung will certainly impress you with this 1080p AMOLED display for sure.
Last but not least, we left the best part about Galaxy S5 for the end of this video.
The Samsung Galaxy S5's camera is one of the most delightful things about the device.
Its technologically unique and advanced BSI sensor is capable of offering an extreme performance when it comes to photos and videos.
Photo capturing with a resolution of 5312 x 2988 pixels, 4K video, 1080p video at 60FPS, 720p video at 120FPS are enough to render you speechless.
There are several more functions of the Galaxy S5's camera that no one can describe better than the samples we have prepared for you.
Enjoy.

The Samsung Galaxy S5 is available now for 749, no one can hide the fact that the Galaxy S5 is asking for a lot of money and it is targeted at a specific audience, especially in a country like Greece.
We have mentioned in the past that the pricing of high-end smartphones like the Galaxy S5 is inordinate.
599 sound like a better deal although we did expect to see a lot less by Samsung's new flagship device but instead we got a premium experience.
Samsung's biggest mistake is the creation of a big hype around the Samsung Galaxy S5 being a revolutionary smartphone.
It may not fit to that description and some people may still be moaning about its price or its technical specifications but Samsung has one of the most capable smartphones on the market right now.
Stay tuned to Unboxholics for our upcoming in-depth review of Samsung Gear Neo 2.
That's all for today's episode.
See you soon unboxers!
Hey what's up everybody, this is Dom!
Today we are comparing the Galaxy S5 to the iPhone 5S.
Now, I realize these are two completely different devices and it's kinda like comparing apples to oranges, but I thought we would compare the two and see how they differ.
So, one thing you may have noticed already is the size.
Obviously, the Galaxy S five is way bigger than the iPhone 5S.
It's rocking a 5.1 inch display and the iPhone 5S only has a 4-inch display, so that's definitely going to be a huge difference there.
But on the top side of the devices, as you can see we have a headphone jack, an infrared blaster and a microphone on the S5, where we just have a lock button on the iPhone 5S.
Taking a look at the side of the devices, as you can see, the iPhone 5S has a SIM card slot whereas the Galaxy S5 just has a lock button.
The SIM card slot for the S5 is under its back panel.
Now, taking a look at the bottom of the devices, here's where things get a little bit different.
We have a speaker and microphone on the 5S, a lightning port and a headphone jack.
The Galaxy S5 has just one USB 3.0 charging and sync port.
Moving on to the other side, as you can see both devices have volume controls, but the iPhone 5s does have a mute switch on the side as well.
One feature that both these devices do have in common is a fingerprint scanner that's built around the home button.

Now, the iPhone 5s is a bit easier only requiring you to rest your finger on the sensor in order to activate it, whereas the Galaxy S5 actually makes you swipe across the home button to use it, but it does allow you make mobile payments using Pay Pal.
Like I said, you do have to swipe your finger across this in order to set it up and whenever you would like to use it and you've got to be pretty precise with your swipes.
If you don't do it exactly the same, it's gonna give you a little error and tell you to do it again, but it was fairly accurate in my testing.
Though I think it's a lot easier and smoother on the iPhone 5S with touch ID.

Taking a look at the back side of these devices the S5 overalls the 8-megapixel camera found on the iPhone 5S, with a 16 megapixel camera that is capable of shooting 4K videos at 30 frames per second.
And yeah, there's also a heart rate sensor in case you cared about that for some reason.

I don't find it to be that big of a deal, but it could be helpful for people that are into that kind of lifestyle that really need to check their heart rate every once in a while and want that feature on the back in their phones.
So, props to Samsung for adding that into the Galaxy S5.
On the front side both devices do have front facing cameras and the appropriate sensors, but that's just about all you'll find here.
One last thing I wanted to take a look at is this accessory.
It's actually a back plate for the Galaxy S5 that will enable wireless charging on the S5.
So, you have to purchase the back plate and then you can purchase the wireless charging pad from Samsung and be able to wirelessly charge or device just by setting it on the pad.
Obviously, this is going to cost you extra, but it's something that the iPhone is not currently capable of in its native form.

Now, just for kicks I just wanted to give you guys this comparison shot of the S5, the S4, the Moto X and the iPhone 5S just so you get an idea on exactly how big the Galaxy S5 is, if you've seen any of the other three devices.
So, I hope you guys enjoy this video and if you did be sure to hit that thumbs up button as it does help out the channel a lot.
And be sure to subscribe for more Galaxy S5 content in the future.
Thanks again for watching everybody, I really appreciate it
This is Dom and have a great day.
Hey guys and welcome to Btekt, it's Basil here with the Samsung Galaxy S5.
We've reviewed the Sony Xperia Z2, we've reviewed HTC's One M8, we've got two premium phones in them.

The Samsung Galaxy S5 is premium on paper it has got great spec and of course, a very powerful processor, not to mention a heart rate monitor on the flip side, a fingerprint scanner below the base and it's the only phone to feature a USB 3.0 port.
It's also one of the last phones to feature a removable back cover giving you the ability to swap out the battery.
There's a lot to love about the Samsung Galaxy S5 from the offset, but is it as good as the competition?
And would we recommend one?
Design We have a white and black Samsung Galaxy S5 with us, and it makes sense that we bring the black one right into frame so we can also bring a black Samsung Galaxy S4, thereby comparing the two.
The first thing we notice is that the back cover is way less glossy.
On the Samsung Galaxy S5 it's completely matte and features a dotted pattern, which feels richer in the hand.
It has also got flatter sides than the Galaxy S4.
It's bigger too, mainly that's down to the waterproofing, but it's significantly bigger.
You've got quite a lot more Samsung Galaxy S5 than you do Samsung Galaxy S4, despite the screen only being 0.1 inches bigger.
You'll also notice the lack of a heart rate monitor on the Galaxy S4.
From the front, the Galaxy S4 and Galaxy S5 are a little more similar.
You can't mistake the Samsung Galaxy S5 as a device from a different lineup.
Turn them around though, and the Galaxy S5 is the more interesting of the two.
The Galaxy S5 is available in a range of colours.
We've got the white and black version, although there's also a blue, brown and gold version available for sale.
We've got to say we're quite big fans of the white Galaxy S5 however.
On the right hand side of the Samsung Galaxy S5, you'll find the power button, while on the base you'll see the new-look micro USB 3.0 port.
The port is covered by a flap, which has been put there simply to ensure the phone is water and dust resistant.
On the left hand side there is the volume rocker, while at the top you have your 3.5mm headphone jack and an IR blaster.
On the back there's the 16MP ISOCELL camera and a heart rate monitor.
As for the size of the Galaxy S5, Samsung's latest flagship fares pretty well.
Up against the HTC One M8, the Galaxy S5 manages to come out looking smaller, despite the larger screen.
The metal HTC One M8 is also heavier than the S5, although it does feel more premium and has HTC's BoomSound speakers, which produce much better sound than the speakers on the Galaxy S5.
The Sony Xperia Z2 even manages to be significantly larger than the Galaxy S5.
Making Samsung's smartphone the most manageable Android flagship of 2014 so far.
The glass front and back of the Sony Xperia Z2 does however make the phone feel a little bit more premium than Samsung's offering.
Against the iPhone 5s however the Samsung Galaxy S5 is a giant.
That's mainly due to the tiny screen on the iPhone.
Display Samsung has equipped the Galaxy S5 with a display that can only be described as "great".
Super AMOLED, full HD, 5.1 inches, on paper it looks virtually identical to its predecessor.
Bringing it closer into frame and you can see you've also got those really nice, punchy colours, deep dark blacks as well.
In the menus for example you can make out very deep blacks.
There are some improvements over its predecessor however, especially when it comes to brightness control.
If you pull down the brightness control all the way, you won't be able to see what's on the screen at all, and that's perfect.
The reason it's perfect is because when reading the display at night it's much more comfortable than any other phone we've ever used.

You've also got the ability to control the way that the screen displays content, so if we jump into screen mode you can see you've got "adapt display", "dynamic", "standard", "professional photo" or "cinema".
If you leave it on adapt display the phone is actually going to cater for whatever application you open, whether it's Google Play Books, or the gallery, or the camera.
This actually does a really good job of tapering colours.
AMOLEDs have habitually over saturated colours to a zealous level, they really look almost neon.
They're so so over the top, but the Galaxy S5 is actually probably the most tapered AMOLED we've used to date.
Comparing the Galaxy S5 against its competitors and you'll see that both Sony and HTC's flagship phones turned out a lot punchier.
The Galaxy S5 on the other hand made colours look a lot more true-to-life and much more pleasing to the eye.
The Galaxy S5's display also offers fantastic viewing angles beating out the competition.
The Samsung Galaxy S5 manages to carry out a balancing act.
You get super vibrant and saturated colours through the UI, which is exactly where you want them, as well as in games.
When you get to the gallery however the colours are a lot more tapered.
Whites aren't as accurate as on the HTC One M8, and there's no white balance control like on the Sony Xperia Z2, but that's pretty much the only area where we saw Samsung's smartphone fall behind.
UI The Galaxy S5 utilises Samsung's latest TouchWiz Magazine UI over the top of Android 4.2.2, the latest version of Android.
Out of the box you'll get three home screens by default, with the option to add more home screens by pinching outwards.
You'll also see some of the default widgets as soon as you boot up the phone.
The first widget you'll see is the weather and clock widget, underneath that you'll see Google's search widget.
Google's search works right from the home screen using voice commands, that means you can just say "OK Google" direct from your home screen and launch a search straight away.
Below that you'll see some app shortcuts, out of the box you'll be offered email, camera, Play Store, and a Google Apps folder.
Rather niftily, Samsung gives you the ability to further customise folders by changing the colours.
Swiping across, the second home screen will have a widget for S Health and Geo News.

aspectTerm.term: widget for S Health and Geo News

sentence.text: S Health has become a staple on Samsung's flagship phones offering loads of health-related features such as speedometer, and on the Galaxy S5 a heart rate monitor.
Geo News is a relatively new function, offering you hyperlocal news.
Geo News will actually inform you of any local flooding or tremors.
Underneath those widgets you'll see two app icons, one for Kids Mode and one for Gallery.
Rather bizarrely, despite showcasing on the home screen Kids Mode isn't preinstalled on the Samsung Galaxy S5.
If you want to use it you'll be required to download it.
This isn't the only app that requires a download before use, despite there being icons for them.
On the third home screen there are widgets for Galaxy Essentials and Galaxy Gifts.
Galaxy Essentials gives you the ability to choose whether or not you want to download some of the Samsung apps that are suggested, but not preinstalled, like Kids Mode.
Galaxy Gifts on the other hand offers up a world of promotional offers exclusive for your phone, such as free music streaming or access to free Amazon Kindle books.
Swipe across to the left of your home screens and you'll see Samsung's My Magazine.
The app is powered by Flipboard, although you'll notice that you're unable to choose Facebook integration -- despite there being options for Google+ and Twitter.
Thankfully Samsung does give you the option to disable My Magazine, since we found it to be quite clunky especially as a newsreader.
There are better newsreaders to be had on the Google Play Store that are standalone apps, rather than built-in to the OS.
Unlike on other operating systems like iOS, Samsung has given folders their own space.
You can't actually let apps and folders coexist, meaning you'll potentially have more home screens than you'd like.

Pull down from the top you have notifications, brightness toggles, S Finder, Quick Connect and some quick toggles, which can be expanded upon or just simply pulled down by default with a two finger swipe.
Quick Connect allows you to connect to other devices in the immediate area via Bluetooth or WiFi Direct.
If you have a Bluetooth headset and want to connect it, but not entirely sure how Bluetooth works, Quick Connect is much easier to go through than the Bluetooth menu.
S Finder will search your entire phone for whatever you type.
If you search "Samsung", you'll get a search back for applications, music files, settings and web history.
In the quick toggle menu you'll notice two rather new items listed.
One of them is download booster, while the other is toolbox.
Download booster when activated will boost your download speeds by using WiFi connectivity and your data network speed, whether it be 3G or 4G, together to give you a significant speed boost.
Toolbox on the other hand is a lot like Facebook's Chat Heads.
You'll be given a white orb that you can place anywhere on the screen.
Tapping the white button will give you quick shortcuts to a plethora of applications which you can customise.

aspectTerm.term: quick shortcuts to a plethora of applications

sentence.text: If you want to quickly launch Facebook or Camera from anywhere in the UI, this could be the quickest way of doing it.
Overall, our impression of TouchWiz is that it's really improved.
There are a few issues however.
Quick Connect managed to suck our battery and has been quite faulty every now and then, but it's been a problem exclusively with our white Galaxy S5.
We're happy to see the old version of TouchWiz go.
The design of the Magazine UX is much more attractive.
Just hopping into settings will be further evidence as to why this is one of the most beautiful iterations of Android we've ever seen.
Fingerprint Scanner The Samsung Galaxy S5 also has a fingerprint scanner, you can use it to unlock your phone or to make secure payments through the PayPal app.

aspectTerm.term: secure payments through the PayPal app

sentence.text: You can also make folders and other things on your phone private, requiring a fingerprint scan to access them.
You can have up to three fingers activate the fingerprint scanner.
It doesn't always work but it does seven times out of ten.
It works with more than just your finger, it also works with your thumb.
There has been evidence of people being able to bypass this security, but it's not something to be overly concerned about.
If your fingerprint fails, don't worry you won't be locked out, as there is a code you can enter.
S Health Given the Samsung Galaxy S5 has a heart rate monitor, it makes sense to talk about S Health.
Opening the application and you'll notice three icons right at the top.
One is a pedometer, in the middle is a calories burned indicator, while the third is your food intake.
At the bottom you can access three different settings, whether it be Pedometer, Exercise or Heart Rate.
Tapping through to heart rate, the heart rate monitor on the back of the device will be activated.
Swiping in from the left and you get a few more options to play with.
You can enter your weight and set calorie goals, perfect for keeping fit.
While the coach option talks you through what you should do to lose weight.
Think of it as a personal trainer in your pocket.
Camera Activating the 16 megapixel camera on the Galaxy S5 is easy.
All you need to do is swipe from the lock screen or tap the camera shortcut.
Taking a picture is very quick and focusing is extremely fast.
You're better off tapping to focus before snapping a picture however, as the camera has a tendency to not focus without a tap first.
While the Samsung Galaxy S5 takes a pretty decent shot, there's quite a lot of evidence of post-processing to sharpen everything up.
We'd argue that it doesn't take as good of a picture as the likes of the Sony Xperia Z2, but images are a lot more detailed than on the HTC One M8.
Despite that, the Samsung Galaxy S5 doesn't have as many manual controls.
We have to say that the Samsung Galaxy S5's camera UI is one of our favourites, and we'd definitely prefer it over almost every other.
It's extensively customisable.
You have the option for front-facing camera, background defocus, HDR, camera flash and a toggle button on the left hand side.
Tapping to the toggle and you'll be hit with countless of settings that you can choose to have on the left hand side, rather than the standard ones mentioned earlier.
Background defocus works quite well, but you'll have to be close to your object and it can take quite some time.
A lot longer than the HTC One M8, or Xperia Z2.
Alongside the plethora of options, there's also tons of shooting modes.
What's more is that you can download as many shooting modes as there are available in the app store.
We have to say that the automatic mode however is a joy.
Picture quality is really strong and nice and vibrant.
The flash is also very very bright.
As far as video goes, the Galaxy S5 shoots in a load of formats.
There's 4k, full HD and 720p options, if you really want to sacrifice file size however you've also got the option to try out VGA.
You also get multiple speeds to choose from, whether it be slow-motion, fast-motion or smooth motion.
The latter of which is 60fps.
Slow-motion is also complete with a ton of different speeds, an eighth, quarter or half speed.
Which is perfect for those of you who like to tinker.
Slower speeds however are shot at 720p and there is no UI to slow down certain things like on iOS and Sony's TimeShift Video on the Xperia Z2.
Multimedia The Samsung Galaxy S5's screen is just itching to be enjoyed, whether it's apps like Netflix, your own movies, photos, they're going to look fantastic.
In bright sunlight the blacks may get a little bit same but that's as we said only really noticeable in bright sunlight.
Otherwise they look very deep and colours look really nice and saturated.
We were a little disappointed by the placement of the speaker however, it's incredibly easy to cover up.
You'll better off utilising separate headphones or a bluetooth speaker.
Gaming on the Galaxy S5 is an absolute treat.
The large 5.1-inch Super AMOLED display ensure that on-screen controls are no problem whatsoever and performance is no issue either.
You can even run more than one game in the background without having to sacrifice performance.
We'd say that this is one of the best gaming phones on the market, as long as you don't account for sound quality, since you're going to want to plug in some external headphones.
Performance The Galaxy S5's performance is incredibly impressive.
The 2GB of RAM and Qualcomm Snapdragon 801 processor really nails it.
It's smoother than both the Galaxy S4 and Galaxy Note 3, despite the latter of which featuring 3GB of RAM.
The UI has been streamlined and the ability to turn off My Magazine is a godsend.
We'd go so far as to say that this is the most powerful Samsung Galaxy on the market right now, or at least the most optimised.
As connections go, you've got everything and the kitchen sink.
You don't have wireless charging as standard like on the upcoming Nokia Lumia 930, but you can get a wireless charging back plate for it.
You've got an IR blaster, USB 3.0 and it's water resistant.
The battery life on the Samsung Galaxy S5 is nothing to phone home about, and after about a day, you won't be able to phone home at all.
You can turn ultra power saving mode on but it takes an age to activate and disables a ton of applications it thinks are going to use battery.
You still get internet access though, which is more than the HTC One M8's ultra power saving mode does.
You also have access to the likes of Facebook, Twitter and Google+ however, but don't expect access to the camera.

Given the Samsung Galaxy S5's battery is user replaceable, you can always carry spares if you feel like you're not going to be able to last until the next charge, negating the need to go into ultra power saving mode.
You should be able to find the batteries readily available on places like eBay or through official retailers.
Conclusion The Samsung Galaxy S5 was always going to be a good phone, the question was always going to be how good is it, and it is very good.
There are some key advantages over the competition, such as the swappable back cover being the main one, and being able to replace the battery.
It's also the most ergonomic and easiest to reach all the corners.
We're also glad to see the back of the glossy design of the Galaxy S4, and the Galaxy S5's matte backing is much more preferable.
The display is also beautiful, the UI is much much preferred over TouchWiz Nature UX of old.
There are a few points of contention, we did have a few battery issues, for the most part though you should get at least a full day out of this phone.
We'd also say there's a lot of gimmicks on the device, the heart rate monitor or fingerprint scanner for instance aren't strong enough reasons to opt for the Galaxy S5 over its competition.
The camera does perform very well, and once again you have a very solid Galaxy device from Samsung.
The Samsung Galaxy S4 was a record-breaking all-time sales record for Samsung.

It may have been made out of plastic and rainy heavily skinned Android software, but it was a great Android device for millions and let's face it, Android wouldn't be where they are now without Samsung
So, when Samsung scratches their heads to make the new flagship we all tend to look, the result is the Samsung Galaxy S5.
Now I've used this device for the past two weeks and I'm ready to give you my full review.
So here it is.
This is probably one of the most important reviews I will do in 2014, so let's get it right.
The Samsung Galaxy S5 is Samsung's fifth generation flagship device.
It shares a lot of DNA with the previous Samsung Galaxy S models.
What's new this year is just about everything.
The screen size has been bumped up to 5.1 inches, but it keeps the same resolution of 1920 by 1080.
The Snapdragon 600 processor has been swapped for a more powerful 801 chip.
The RAM remains at two gigabytes.
The camera has been bumped up to 16 megapixels.
One of the interesting new features is the back case, which reminds me a lot of the Motorola Moto X.
It doesn't have quite the same texture or the feeling, but it does feel a lot better than the slippery glossy plastic found on the Samsung Galaxy S4.
Yes! The S5 actually feels the heck of a lot better in the hand than the S4, which is strange because besides from the back cover they're basically built up of the same material
The other main difference between the S4 and S5 in terms of aesthetic design is the corners.
Now, the S4 is more rounded and the five is more straight, but that's about it.
Taking a look around the phone, you'll see the slight changes on where the things are placed.
For example, the headphones jack is now on the left side.
Also, you'll see a new cover door for the micro USB 3 charging port.

aspectTerm.term: cover door for the micro USB 3 charging port

sentence.text: This sort of reminds me of a sliding door on the Samsung Galaxy S2, but it's a lot less cooler than the door.
You are probably wondering why you need a cover to protect the micro USB ports.
Well, if you also lifted up the back cover you'll see its rubber gasket.
This phone is IP 67 rated, which means it's able to stand being submerged into one meter of water for 30 minutes.
Now, you can go scuba diving with it, but you can't drop it in the sink.
But, let's face it, the most common thing to do is dropping it in the toilet and that shouldn't cause it too much harm.
And if you and dropped in the toilet and flushed it down, it's ruined anyway.
So, here's a glass of water and here's the Samsung Galaxy S5.
We'll just drop it in for a few seconds and make sure our phone still works.
And there we go, works just fine.
Next, I wanna talk about the display again.
I'll take color accuracy over saturation any day.
That's why I enjoy watching things in IPS displays like the M8's, but I do have to say the Samsung Galaxy S5 five has probably one of the best if not the best displays currently on the market.
I'm a hundred percent completely sold.
I don't care how not accurate my colors are, just look at everything.
It absolutely pops.
Then we move on to the home button.
You might be asking: "why, it's just a button".
Or is it?
Samsung has rather cleverly placed the fingerprint reader underneath the home button, similar to touch ID on the iPhone 5.
Now, this will allow you to lock your device and use your fingerprint as the password.
The only trouble is that it works about fifty percent of the time.
Since the home button's about one fourth the size of your finger you actually have to swipe down, unlike the iPhone where just simply place your finger on top of the home button.
So the slightest wiggle or off-angle finger and you'll get this: a fingerprint error.
So, then it becomes more of a hassle rather than a security step to protect your phone.
So, please use a different type a security measurement.
Next on the list is the heart rate monitor.
This is probably the funniest most gimmicky thing on the new S5.
Why?
Because if you have a phone with a flash and some kind of AppStore you already have a heart rate monitor.
Just google it, it's on the AppStore.
There's tons of them.
Mac Mixing actually made a video displaying how accurate those third-party applications are to the sold one built on S5.
So, anyway, it's positioned beneath the camera, just right to the flash and uses a red light to measure your pulse.
And actually works considerably well, a lot better than the fingerprint reader.
But will I be using this feature on an everyday basis?
Not really.
It makes much more sense to have a heart rate monitor on a watch since it'll have a constant contact point with your skin.
So, if you want a heart rate monitor by one of the new Samsung Gear watches.
Next, let's take a deep dive into the software of the S5.
It runs Android 4.4.2 KitKat, with the latest version of their TouchWiz software.
Actually, we don't wanna refer to it as TouchWiz, but basically it's TouchWiz
I've actually that were toned down in touch was a previous models in Note 3 and the S4, and it does feel a lot more snappy than all those previous generations.
It's a little bit more tailored rather than Samsung's own software, but the experience is a lot more snappy than in the S4.
Now, part of that is mainly because of software revamp but also because of the new quad-core 801 chip from Snapdragon.
That's pretty comparable to the actual 600 processor found on the S4.
The performances are not that big of a difference.
Again GeekBench will tell you a big different story, but in personal personal usage it's not that much faster.
Through the menu you can see little subtle changes in the UI, but you can obviously see the DNA that has been passed in it.
I guess with time we'll see a lot less off the skin but it's a good start for Samsung.
One thing I do like is the menu structure within the settings.
It just reminds me of a mixture of iOS and maybe Web OS and Android.
I don't know if I'm the only one who actually likes this type of set up, but I do like it for the most part.
And for the most part, TouchWiz is massively improved.
Throughout the entire software and applications and Google Chrome the S5 hills it like a champ, which is not an easy thing to say for Samsung Galaxy S4.
That phone actually had trouble running its own soft run in a few places.
There's only one part of a software that this phone still has a hard time handling.
It's in My Magazine.

And in the backbone of this comes Flipboard, which runs absolutely fine, but for some reason this My Magazine feature on the Samsung Galaxy S5 will slow down, especially when fired up for the first time that day.
Now, My Magazine is not a feature I would use on a regular basis.
I only used this for the sole purpose of reviewing this phone.
I found it not to be entirely useful because it's not as flexible as things like Blink Feed or sole applications like My News applications.
Now, the biggest shift in this industry this year is the focus on battery life.
I think this year or the year next will be the biggest game changers in battery performance and you don't have to thank the people who make your batteries, but it's the people writing your software.
The Samsung Galaxy S5 has an ultra power saving mode which basically turns the entire phone off, except the phone's still on.

You can select the applications you want to run while in this mode, but things like WiFi and Bluetooth constant updating and even the color pixels are simply switched off and you have this gray scale display.
This mode will give you a little under two weeks of battery life on a full charge.
Though the software is not aesthetically pleasing, it will be a huge boost when you lose your charger or you're stuck in a deserted island like Lost.
You never know when that stuff happens.
When you're not in power saving mode, battery offers a solid day of usage and you don't have to carry around a charger to make it through a full day, which is always a plus.
Performance's rock-solid.
You won't see huge performance gains compared to the Samsung Galaxy S4, but GeekBench will tell you otherwise.
You also notice the speed differences when you browse the web or run intensive applications that take advantage of the new Adrenal 330 graphics card.
But for everyday usage you won't see the difference.
Then we get to the camera.
Samsung is not too far away from Sony or Nokia phone manufacturers, with a huge mega pixel count.
This one has 16 megapixels. In fact the photos of the S5 look great, just as good as the iPhone 5S, a million times better than the HTC One in detail, but they do have a cold hutsy venom.
But the detail of the photos are breathtaking, even in these low light shots the details are crisp.
Now there is a bit of noise but you can expect that with any camera, especially if one with a 16 megapixel count.
The video's also not bad.
It shoots 4K, but that's a lie.
4K is 4096 by 2160 and this shoots a more web friendly UHD video at 3840 by 2160.
The video does lack OIS, yes, but the autofocus is absolutely killer on this video.
I actually have a separate clip uploaded to the phoneDog YouTube channel about the S5 showing a UHD video very shortly.
That was a lot of information.
Now, we try to put it in more simple terms.
KDHE put the S5 in the best terms, I think I've never heard differently since the S5 was announced.
But this is basically or essentially the S4S from Samsung.
Well, I know what you guys are saying: "Well, the S4 was the S model of the S3".
Well, I do agree with you, it's not a radical change from basically the last three or four years of Samsung Galaxy phones, but again you have to think how hard it is to really redesign a phone.
I'm not a phone engineer, I don't build those, but I can't even imagine how hard it is for engineers to sit down and actually brainstorm ideas.
Now I'm sure you guys have plenty of ideas, but you have to make them practical, you know, something that Samsung can afford.
Now, you still have to make money off this phone, so obviously we can just jam in, you know, space lasers, whatever you want into the S5, but again vast's vast.
Now, I am left with a little bit of disappointment for Samsung.
Why?
Because this isn't really the phone I wanted from Samsung.
I wanted something completely different.
I wanted something more of the lines of the HTC One from Samsung, with a metal built, with a really awesome software, I'm talking about like Google software, Google partnership.
Now, that is gonna happen in the future.
I know Samsung and Google are becoming more friends now, so hopefully we'll have some kind of Samsung Galaxy Nexus device that's high-quality premium and something that doesn't run TouchWiz.
And yes, the S5 might still be one the best Android devices in 2014.

Now we don't want to call it best phone just yet, because what we're still in 2014 and we have a kind of dogfight between the HTC One versus the S5 and we'll see which one comes out on top that dogfight, which will be coming very soon, so stay tuned.
But again, this is one of the best Android devices so far.
Now I am still very disappointed from Samsung not to see so much radical change.
But again, maybe we're expecting too much from the spot on manufacturers to put all great new features on every single device.
So, that's basically the story for Samsung Galaxy S5.

It's the best Samsung Galaxy S device that I've used so far, but again we say that for every single device that comes up, like the new HTC One, the new iPhone, the new LG G3, whatever you wanna call it, every single phone will be better than the phone before it.
But again, this phone is the best S4 model that you can get.
So if you want a brand new Samsung Galaxy device, just buy the S5.
Why not buy the S4?
Because it's technology, you get more technology and more features on the Samsung Galaxy S5.
For the things like the heart rate monitor and the fingerprint scanner, those things are pretty much gimmicks for me.
I don't see why they are necessary, especially if they were implemented in such a poor way.
The fingerprint reader on the S5, which works about fifty percent of the time, is just not the useful thing to have on this device.
I would have wanted something more, like OIS on the video camera to make the 4K video look absolutely amazing, something that the HTC One lacks, something the iPhone lacks.
So, maybe that's what Samsung should have invested in, things that we actually use every single day.
